data.message: Yup, check angular, ember, react, and brothers. Another thing, "separation of concern" is a case-by-case thing. Doing the above side by side my business logic is a personal decision, I could do it and live with the maintenance hell I put my self in. Or I could separate business logic and my UI logic as much as I can and have a little bit better maintenance burden.
Shady M. Najib but do we really need to write UI code in 2015? Should we? Shouldn't there be something like VStudio and VB days when it was just drag and drop and properties?
Really? انت مقتنع؟ :D How do you do your current projects UI, now?
For business Apps, either Windows UI or SP web parts or ASP.NET Webforms.

The web app of today should work on different devices, with different screen sizes. An internet connection is not always available, so your app should be able to work offline. The data flow is not a client request & server response model. The server can push updates to your app. You also want to implement all of this efficiently.

You need to apply the ViewModel pattern to the UI, and with it you need controllers (to handle different UI events), repository pattern (to abstract the difference between backend service & local storage), concurrency control, caching, performance.

Think of Facebook, Gmail, Google maps, etc. Even if you're working on an inventory system, if you know you've 100K materials, you will use auto-complete from the start, not a drop down.

It has been sometime since I used jQuery like this. The last time I wrote it, it was for a static website. See, jQuery is the shell script of the web. You can't create Gmail with jQuery, or shell scripts.

Mohammad Tayseer the idea is you can use controls like Telerik to do stuff like that and they handle all that behaviour for you, there is no reason a developer with  a valuable brain should be wasting his valuable time doing presentation layer stuff, unless you are making a game maybe. As for offline versions on an inventory system, you would use a windows application or even GTK for that, not a web application for sure. In ERP systems it is important to take advantage of client processing power and a 3-tier approach makes a lot of sense.  As for MVC, I really see no need to use that unless you like the pattern or there is a specific need that warrants its use, which is pretty rare. In terms of GMAIL, Google maps and FB, they are just that, no one wants there ERP experience to be anything like that and it is never worth the time or investment or even considered an enhancement, they would rather have more fine grained control over the financial tree.  Amazingly, most simple websites don't really require all the complexity you talk about.  :)

1- If you're building simple websites, you won't write jQuery for hours :)

2- Front-end engineer is associated with larger websites

3- Telerik/Angular/Ember/React/... are all valid options, but you still have to write code

4- Desktop apps require deployment on devices. Web apps don't

5- >  As for MVC, I really see no need to use that unless you like the pattern or there is a specific need
It depends on what you're building

6- > no one wants their ERP experience to be anything like that

On the other hand, no one said that front-end frameworks is for everyone.

We wanted to demo a cloud management system to some investors. We created the UI with Angular. We used Angular dependency injection to mock the backend services. The mocks used browser localStorage.
